Topic.Title: Potential Intel Options Strategy

Message.Msg: Yes make sure however you enter the trade only when the stock is at -2sd (20 day band) or less (requires patience that you can abort only if you feel confident the stock is about to go a lot higher and there is no time for serious drop first). You will then have massive edge and of course even better pocket difference or maybe a smarter thing like sell 1 and buy 2. But only when the sky is falling and everyone is cursing the universe you should be entering such trades unless the leap call volatility is larger than the put's Basically ideally you enter that trade during a not very violent market period but one where the stock is oversold after many down days. Also make sure the puts you are selling correspond to cash you have that could support stress free an exercise without then being forced right away to liquidate position (or find yourself at huge margin) at loss if say a market mini crash or worse took place and you were forced to buy there and it kept down. Fat chance for

Message.Title: Intel's IDF: Reinventing the PC with a 2 for 1 Computer Deal
Message.Msg: Coming from PatentlyApple, this article shows all the more why good times are ahead for Intel. And just over the last 2 weeks, this same publication had an article on Apple possibly coming out with a Hybrid Mac-iPad device - a laptop with a detachable screen. ARM can do Tablets and Smartphones now....but can they compete with Bay Trail Tablets and Merrifield Smartphones. More importantly, can they even have an entre into the 2-for-1 convertibles and detachables form factor? I think not. ================================== The New Ultrabook Convertible and Detachable Category Gives Consumers a 2 for 1 Computer Deal The main keynote delivered at IDF Beijing 2013 last week titled "Reinventing the Intel Computing Experience" was delivered by Kirk Skaugen, Senior VP, General Manager PC Client Group. Early into Skaugen's keynote he made the observation that at the end of the day "we're all both consumption and creation people. On one hand, we consume news on our phones and tablets every day. But we're also creation people. So there's room for a new and exciting category that we're calling the Ultrabook Convertible and Detachable. Simply put it's a 2 for 1 computing device that's the best of a PC with a full quad core experience and a fantastic tablet." If there was one message that Intel hammered home at IDF Beijing, it was definitely that the coming wave of Ultrabook Convertible products arriving this summer will deliver the very best 2 for 1 computer deal and experience that the industry has to offer. The multiple slides presented during Skaugen's keynote and throughout IDF prove this out. Below are some of the slides that repeat their new 2013 marketing message. patentlyappleDOTcom/patently-apple/2013/04/intels-idf-reinventing-the-pc-with-a-2-for-1-computer-deal.html

Message.Title: Can the Cisco Foundry deal be announced tomorrow?
Message.Msg: With Ashraf's previous post on Intel Custom Foundry job ad (mentioning Cisco), this has to be one of the industry's worst kept secrets. The key question is will they announce the deal tomorrow. A billion dollar added revenue with 50%+ margins would be good for guidance! ===================== Cisco has to fab chips at an Intel foundry Analysis: It isn't a choice as much as a requirement Apr 15, 2013 by Charlie Demerjian Cisco is going to make chips with Intel as a foundry for one simple reason, they have to. Why they have to do so is a simple question with an equally simple answer if you have the background to understand it. In the foundry space there are five main players, TSMC, Global Foundries, Samsung, IBM, and now Intel. From there you get to a bunch of second tier players that we will ignore for the time being. It is unlikely that a company with Cisco’s technical needs could find their fab needs met by the B-squad of the process world. Most companies that want to fab with Intel need bleeding edge process tech anyway and are willing to pay to get it. If you had to rank these five vendors on a process quality basis it would go Intel then other with not much to choose from between the others. Each new process brings a new set of stumbles, and over time they average out to rough parity. Sometimes one is way ahead, sometimes one stumbles, but none of these are consistently ahead of the other four. semiaccurateDOTcom/2013/04/15/cisco-has-to-fab-chips-at-an-intel-foundry/

Message.Title: Fab u less
Message.Msg: Lu is not particularly concerned about Intel (INTC) and Samsung Electronics (005930KS) as competitors, he writes. Taiwan Semi has proven it can handle “millions of wafers with different designs, all within the promised schedule and with steady yields,” which neither Intel nor Samsung can necessarily achieve. Moreover, the competitive landscape suggests there is a limit to how many “fabless” chip makers can move to Intel or Samsung, as many have competitive issues with both giants:

Topic.Title: Oh, for those halcyon days of April 10th

Message.Msg: suckks to be you

Topic.Title: Fab u less

Message.Msg: more from the article; No, Lu’s real issue is that the return it’s going to get on the explosion of chips for mobile devices will not be as rich going forward as it was in past, both in terms of semiconductor content and the diminishing returns of smaller feature sizes: From 2010 to 2013, TSMC’s total revenues grew by US$8 billion. Within that, around US$4.5 billion came from an increase in smartphone/tablet revenues. If our analysis is correct in that smartphone units continue to grow but semi content starts to decrease, from 2013 to 2015, we estimate that smartphone/tablet related revenues only grow by US$3 billion. Within the incremental US$3 billion, we assume around half of it comes from TSMC’s share gain with Apple. This means for the other handset/tablet makers, total revenues only grow by US$1.5 billion over the next two years, despite an incremental 570 million units, mainly because content per device goes down [...] Looking ahead, at 20nm, several of the world’s leading customers have complained that the performance increase relative to the previous node is not as big as in previous nodes, and the cost increase is more. This makes 20nm economically unattractive. We therefore think 20nm could be a node that ramps more slowly than 28nm. We also do not see this problem going away. While TSMC is accelerating 16nm development to entice customers to move ahead, our concern is that the risk/reward is becoming more skewed towards the negative.

Message.Title: My expectation for "after earnings"
Message.Msg: I don't expect much change. Tight range-boundedness (unless outlook is grim, but I don't expect that). Yepp, they'll pump Haswell, Atom, may even announce CSCO, and other "mystery" clients in waiting...but ho--hum...it's just another day. Outlook, IMO:..weak PC environment persists, strong server environment (remember, a 10-12% increase in server sales can offset a 3-4% drop in PC client sales). Status of 14nm: good. Maybe even a surprise or two...good at onesies twosies % R level. ho-hum Romit Shah will sound a liitle nervous, [like the guy you have to talk to on a Monday when a dell disk drive fails, "Frank" (in New Dehli) who had too much Kingfisher the night before]. when he asks his usual stupid questions, and the INTC guys will unzip and qiss all over him, but he'll go back and write some scathingly preposterous tale of doom and gloom for INTC...Covello too. ho-hum. Earnings will by $0.46; they'll announvce a divvy increase ina few weeks from $0.90 up to $0.94. World's best company, best products..it's even basic research... but I don't expect the wall street gang to show the slightest interest in it. Range bound, just hobbling along the roadside with the market, losing ground to the JNJ's and PG's, etc. Yepp-- I don't expect much to change. (the above is just my opinion...I KNOW nothing).

Message.Msg: INTC has been buying back a lot of stock, and trying to support the shares. Topic.Title: ARM Down Over a Buck

Message.Msg: The INTC options in the area of $21 to $22 are hitting the 10,000 contract level. They are buying puts a little deeper than expected with 6k put contracts at $20 and higher on the calls with 9k at $22.50 but the Intel share price still reflects the attraction of $21.50 based on long straddle/strangle purchases. They are putting on some big option bets for volatilty but in doing that, they drain all the volatility out of the price movement. Interesting day so far.

Topic.Title: Cisco has to fab chips at an Intel foundry

Message.Msg: Another interesting point he raised was the issue of pricing. He suggested that Intel was value pricing their foundry access. If so, that would likely drive AAPL away.

Topic.Title: Cisco has to fab chips at an Intel foundry

Message.Msg: Value pricing - here's what Paul said three months ago - Charlie should quote.... not sure what TSMC current pricing model is - Well, I mean, we are pricing real time with customers, so it's not per wafer. Most people are now pricing, the foundries are pricing per die or per millimeter square and that tends to be the model that we would use here to for the most part depending on this level of technology we are talking about. The pricing here is going to be value-based pricing. I mean, obviously it has to be competitive, but the value that we bring in terms of the technology is I think pretty exceptional.

In the mean time we are paying interest on the bonds for the buy back and paying dividends on the stock we haven't bought back yet.

Message.Title: Intel Shows Demo Video of Cheap 100Gb/sec Silicon Photonics Chip
Message.Msg: Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) Shows Demo Video of Cheap 100Gb/sec Silicon Photonics Chip By Michael Aragon • April 12, 2013 • Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) has presented a demo of what is being touted as the world’s only silicon photonics module that uses a hybrid silicon laser. If this is true, it will allow such advances as vastly improved system-to-system interconnects in the data center. The 100Gb/sec module was demoed in a video during Intel CTO Justin Rattner’s keynote presentation at the Beijing Intel Developer Forum on Thursday. All modulators, detectors, waveguides, circuitry, and the aforementioned laser will be incorporated in garden-variety silicon instead of the hand-built, gallium arsenide based photonics modules such as are presently available, which are expensive. Since integrated silicon photonics modules could be fabbed using existing equipment and tested using a hybrid of conventional and Intel-developed techniques, such speedy modules could be created much more cheaply, and therefore eventually work their way into far more devices and systems. Sun Microsystems cofounder and current Arista Networks chairman and chief development officer Andy Bechtolsheim stated in a discussion with Rattner, that the major obstacle of a 100Gb/sec Ethernet is that it lacks practicality till the price of the optics are slashed down substantially to a reasonable sum. However, he went on to add that due to the technology of silicon photonics modules such as those Intel demonstrated on Thursday, the 100Gb/sec will be extremely viable for the networking industry. The current 100Gb/sec throughput is nowhere near the top end of silicon photonics capabilities, as Rattner said at the Open Compute Conference. When asked about the scalability, he replied that Intel is trying for terabit-per-second throughput. marketnewscallDOTcom/intel-corporation-nasdaqintc-shows-demo-video-of-cheap-100gbsec-silicon-photonics-chip/121002/

Message.Title: Haswell-E supports DDR4: Tons of Computing Power
Message.Msg: 4-channel memory Even before Ivy Bridge-E hits the market, Intel is busy working on a successor to this ultra high end processor simply codenamed Haswell E. Ivy Bridge-E is on schedule to launch in Q3 2013, using the same LGA 2011 socket, existing X79 chipset as well as four channel DDR3 1866 support. There have been some rumours that Intel even considered cancelling this chipset in favour of speeding up the launch of Haswell-E, the next generation high end enthusiast chip, but so far that hasn’t been announced to partners. Haswell-E has support for upcoming DDR4 memory as well four channel memory, promising much more bandwidth compared to the previous generation. It comes with up to 12 or 16 cores and should deliver tons of computing power. Looking at the server side of things, four channel DDR4 memory and 12 to 16 cores will make a great chip for high end servers and sitting at 130W. It won't save a lot of trees in the Amazon, but it will offer a lot of compute power. At current schedule Haswell-E should show up in later part of 2014, in case Intel doesn’t change its mind and speed up the introduction of this new enthusiast core. From Fudzilla

Message.Title: Shorts Earnings Worry Poll - Final Edition
Message.Msg: The largest danger to shorts on earnings is: 1.) A revenue beat 2.) An earnings beat 3.) Improved Guidance 4.) Announcement of the Cisco deal. 5.) Announcement of the foundry deal involving a major mobility player. 6.) Announcement of a deal with Apple, either foundry or iWatch. 7.) Announcement of a formal start date for the web TV project. 8.) Announcement of the new CEO 9.) A combination of these. 10.) Something else:____________

Topic.Title: Intel should get some good lookin babe for CEO. I am tired of

Message.Msg: Renée J. James reminds me of Adele - just kidding. First I thought Stacy but it looks Dadi is a very likely candidate - Prior to his current role, Perlmutter was senior vice president and general manager of the Mobility Group, where he drove the creation of Intel's latest mobile products from the high-performance Intel® Core™ processor family to the low-power Intel® Atom™ processor family which enabled the netbook segment and allowed Intel to enter the ultra-low power handheld market. As vice president and general manager of the Mobile Platforms Group, he developed the first Intel® Centrino® brand processor technology, which grew the mobile business and became the foundation for all future mobile products.
